title: 115_hr3004
content: This Act, known as "Kate's Law," amends Section 276 of the Immigration and Nationality Act to address illegal reentry of removed aliens. The Act, known as "Kate's Law," amends Section 276 of the Immigration and Nationality Act to address illegal reentry of removed aliens, imposing fines and imprisonment for those who reenter the United States after being denied admission or deported. The Act, known as "Kate's Law," imposes fines and imprisonment for aliens who reenter the United States after being denied admission or deported. The penalties range from 30 months to 25 years depending on the offense, including murder, rape, kidnapping, terrorism, or multiple felonies. The Act, known as "Kate's Law," imposes fines and imprisonment for aliens who reenter or attempt to enter the United States, with penalties of up to 10 years in prison under title 18, United States Code. Prior convictions are elements of the crimes, and affirmative defenses may apply with the consent of the Secretary of Homeland Security. In a criminal proceeding, an alien cannot challenge the validity of any prior removal order. Any alien removed before completing their term of imprisonment faces penalties for reentering the United States. Any alien who enters or attempts to enter the United States after deportation will be incarcerated for the remaining sentence without parole or supervised release unless Homeland Security consents to reentry. Penalties for reentering include other consequences as per the law. The term "crosses the border" refers to physically crossing, regardless of official restraint. The term 'felony' refers to a criminal offense punishable by imprisonment exceeding 1 year, while 'misdemeanor' refers to an offense punishable by imprisonment of 1 year or less. 'Removal' encompasses denial of admission, exclusion, deportation, or any agreement for an alien's removal. 'State' includes U.S. states, the District of Columbia, and commonwealths. The term 'State' includes U.S. states, the District of Columbia, and any commonwealth, territory, or possession of the United States. The House of Representatives passed the document on June 29, 2017, with Karen L. Haas as the Clerk.
